answers.author: Leslie Beauregard
answers.text:
We don't have a threshold but typically for any grant, the department head has to approve a grant proposal.   I have attached our pre-grant application proposal form that's submitted to the Budget Office and the Finance Accountant in charge of grants.  When it comes time for signatures though, the City Manager or COO/CFO are the only ones who can sign off on a grant application.

answers.author: Mercy Montgomery
answers.text:
City staff must submit a staff report outlining basic information about the grant, such as fiscal impact, to Council for approval. 
Occasionally, funding opportunities are identified so close to the submission deadline that staff reports are submitted to Council after the grant is filed and Council must ratify the filing.  An example is attached.

answers.author: Toby Cotter
answers.text:
We require that all grants be approved by a staff grant committee and then by the City Council before submittal. We are going to seek a modification on this rule because there are smaller grants available today that really don't need to go to the City Council. For example, the City receives a grant from Target for National Night Out. I'm going to ask the Council to move the threshold to $5,000 before a grant submittal needs City Council approval. All grants would still require final signatures by the City Manager.

author: Philip Freeman
text: Does your local government have thresholds for who can approve a department to pursue specific grants? For example, could an Assistant Manager, Department Head, or Grants Specialist give the OK for a department to pursue a grant worth some figure (i.e., $5,000 or less) -- or does the County/City Manager have to approve every grant proposal?
title: Thresholds for Grant Approvals
